choices.D: Balanced mode does not provide user load balancing, but it provides in the event of an outage. Active/standby mode provides an always on standby node in the event of an outage, but it does not provide load balancing.
choices.B: Balanced mode provides user load balancing and user failover only for manually generated failovers. Active/standby mode provides an unconfigured standby node in the event of an outage, but it does not provide load balancing.
choices.C: Balanced mode provides user load balancing and user failover in the event of an outage. Active/standby mode provides an always on standby node in the event of an outage, but it does not provide load balancing.
choices.A: Balanced mode provides user load balancing and user failover in the event of an outage. Active/standby mode provides an always on standby node in the event of an outage, and it also provides load balancing.

questions.question_text: What is the major difference between the two possible Cisco IM and Presence high-availability modes?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

High Availability
The IM and Presence Service supports high availability for multiple-node deployments.

After you configure a presence redundancy group, you can enable high availability for the group. A pair of nodes is required for high availability. Each node has an independent database and set of users operating with a shared availability database that is able to support common users.

All IM and Presence Service nodes must belong to a presence redundancy group, which can consist of a single IM and Presence Service node or a pair of IM and Presence Service nodes.

You can configure high availability using two different modes:

Balanced mode: This mode provides redundant high availability with automatic user load balancing and user failover in the event that one nodes fails because of component failure or power outage.

Active/standby mode: The standby node automatically takes over for the active node if the active node fails. It does not provide automatic load balancing.

Selected Answer: C
Balanced mode: This mode provides redundant high availability with automatic user load balancing and user failover in the event that one nodes fails because of component failure or power outage.

Active/standby mode: The standby node automatically takes over for the active node if the active node fails. It does not provide automatic load balancing.

questions.question_text: Which type of greeting in the Call Handler configuration in Cisco Unity Connection overrides all other greetings?
questions.answer_description:
Alternate -
Can be used for a variety of special situations, such as vacations or a leave. An alternate greeting overrides all other greetings.
Reference:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/connection/10x/administration/guide/10xcucsagx/10xcucsag080.html

discussion.content:
Answer is C

According to this link: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/unified-communications/unified-presence/data-sheet-c78-729901.html

Fourth paragraph after "Product Overview": IM and Presence Service natively supports standards-based Extensible Messaging and Presence Protocol (XMPP) and SIP for Instant Messaging and Presence Leveraging Extensions (SIP/SIMPLE). As part of this dual-protocol capability, IM and Presence Service offers customers a choice of either rich-featured Cisco Jabber Unified Communications clients or any third-party XMPP-compliant IM and presence client.

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A
C. SIP/SIMPLE is the correct answer. Jabber clients are SIP devices.

comments.content: A is correct. They are SIP devices from call processing perspective but from instant messaging and presence perspective they use XMPP. Question clearly states the we are asked for im&presence, not calling.

questions.answer_description:
An XMPP connection handles the presence information exchange and instant messaging operations for XMPP-based clients.
Reference:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/im_presence/configAdminGuide/10_5_1/CUP0_BK_CE43108E_00_config-admin-guide- imp-105/CUP0_BK_CE43108E_00_config-admin-guide-imp-105_chapter_00.html
questions.question_text: Which protocol is used between Cisco Jabber clients for instant messaging and presence?

An administrator would like to set several Cisco Jabber configuration parameters to only apply to mobile clients (iOS and Android). How does the administrator accomplish this with Cisco Jabber 12.9 and Cisco UCM 12.5?

choices.A: Create a user profile in Jabber Policies
choices.C: Assign the desired configuration file to ג€Mobileג€ Jabber Client Configuration in the Service Profile
choices.B: Deploy jabber-config-user.xml on iOS and Android devices
choices.D: Upload the jabber-config.enc file to TFTP

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
It is C.
In User Management --> User settings --> service profile
in the section "Jabber Client Configuration (jabber-config.xml) Profile", you can upload a config for each type of device (common, desktop or mobile).
I think it should be "D" any clues on this one?

comments.content: Add my previous answer: Common / Desktop / Mobile for load the specific jabber config. Search for "Jabber - Create a Jabber Client Configuration UC Service"
Another source apart is 'On-Premises Deployment for Cisco Jabber 12.5'

You are right, for CUCM 12.5 and later, C is the correct.
If CUCM was an earlier version than 12.5, D would be correct.
on newer CUCM (12.5+) there is a options to use jabber config file on specific set of device (common, mobile and 3 options that I don't remember right now) on Service profile, so, answer C is correct

choices.A: Remove the IM and Presence servers from the Cisco UCM service profile
choices.C: Disable Instant Messaging on IM and Presence
choices.B: Enable Cisco UCM end users for IM and Presence
choices.D: Add the Application Client Users role to the Cisco UCM end users

discussion.content: B and C. See Cisco documentation: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/unified-communications/jabber/213403-configure-jabber-version-12-0-in-phone-m.html

B & C. A is also true IF the IMP servers already existed in the service profile but I think you have to make the assumption this is a new requirement and no IMP servers have been previously applied to the service profile. see the link below
I agree that B C are correct, but from that A is also true

questions.question_text: A customer wants to deploy Cisco Jabber Phone Mode with contacts. Which two configurations are needed to accomplish this goal? (Choose two.)
